values:
I HAVE A JOB!!!!!!!!

It took me 15 months (including my final year at uni when I was applying), 6 months of work experience at seven agencies, and God knows how many hours spent writing applications and attending grad scheme interviews, and I end up being offered a job after a twenty minute chat. Someone up there has a sense of humour.

I start at a major London advertising agency on a global account on Monday (which means I need to find a flat immediately). I'm still slightly stunned, as I walked out of the interview thinking "that was fun, but it's never going to happen". I was expecting to have to prepare for two grad schemes this weekend, instead I've been bouncing around the net looking for flats.

Wow.

Normally I don't post about computer games here, but I'm making an exception for Mass Effect 2 because the voice cast is just so amazing.

Just a few of the names in it: Martin Sheen (President Bartlet!) Yvonne Strahovski, Adam Baldwin, Seth Green, Tricia Helfer, Carrie Ann Moss Michael Hogan (Col. Tigh!)

I have no idea how much it cost, but it was totally worth it, just for the fun of being ordered around by President Bartlet.

Here's a video with more of the actors:
<lj-embed id="4"/>

This is really for anyone in the USA, but season 3 of Chuck starts tonight on NBC at 9pm. If you've watched it before and know it's good, tune in. If you've never tried it before, give it a go. It's a slightly strange, but utterly brilliant show that came far too close to being cancelled, so please watch! 

There's nothing more frustrating for me than seeing a show I love get cancelled because of US ratings I can't change, and I'm really hoping that doesn't happen this time......

So after seeing the create your own TV show meme bouncing round the net, I cracked. assigned me "Space Pirates", but it kinda mutated in my mind into a grand space drama with political elements and crime and conspiracy theories.... kinda like Deep Space 9 meets the Wars of the Roses by way of The Wire....... yeah, it's probably a good thing I'm not a TV producer.

The meme goes like this, feel free to join in!

1. Comment to this post with "I surrender!" and I'll assign you the basis of some tv show idea. (Science fiction show, medical drama, criminal procedure, etc...)
2. Create a cast of characters, including the actors who'd play them
3. Add in any actor photos, character bios and show synopsis that you want.
4. Post to your own journal.

Anyway, on with the show.
"Phoenix"

Show Premise:
30 years ago, scientists on Earth created a stable wormhole across the galaxy to the Pandora sector, a densely-packed area of solar systems with extraordinary resources. Corporations and settlers flooded through to explore and colonise the area.

20 years later, the wormhole from Earth collapsed without explanation. In the sudden power vacuum, alliances formed and fractured. Thousands died in vicious conflicts, until the few remaining factions negotiated a cease-fire. Today, just two years after the end of the war, the sector is slowly rebuilding. Three main groups have emerged to control much of the sector:

The Terran Alliance, made up of remnants of the Earth Navy and based on Terra Prime, the largest colony in the sector,

The Pegasus Corporation, a new conglomerate formed when several companies agreed to pool their resources (and weapons),

The Federation of Free Systems, a nebulous group of smaller players who clubbed together to resist being conquered.

The peace is tenuous and frail, but has brought new opportunities for those willing to operate in the wild space between borders. In this new territory, a former mining facility has become a haven for traders, pirates and smugglers alike. Thanks to its position and popularity, the once abandoned Echo Station has become a home to representatives of all three factions, jockeying for influence.

New to the station are the Phoenix and her crew, “independent contractors” who find themselves drawn into the webs of intrigue and conspiracy that fill the station.


Crew of the Phoenix

Kavan Smith – Captain Marcus Jones
His seemingly relaxed face hides an incredibly sharp mind. Marcus is always looking for an angle, and doesn’t trust anyone outside his crew. Having kept his ship out of the war, he has no intention if becoming involved in post-war politics, but is unwillingly drawn in after his ship is attacked on a courier run from Echo Station. He decides to investigate the attack, and soon finds himself in over his head.


Skeet Ulrich – Jake Clark
Formerly a pilot in the Alliance military, Jake left at the end of the war, planning to retire to a quiet little planet. Unfortunately for him, he got drunk in the wrong bar and woke up in the Phoenix’s medical bay with three bullets in his chest. He agreed to join the crew “just for a while”, and is still there two years later.


Sprague Grayden – Emma Wright
Highly capable, Emma has proven equally skilled at fixing people and machines. She keeps the crew, and the ship, running, and is good at fixing the junk they find “along the way”. Has a not-so-secret crush on Jake, and treats Jason like a little brother.


David Blue – Jason Wills
Son of a rich family on Terra Prime, Jason left home as soon as possible to avoid joining the Pegasus Corporation. Joined the crew after he was arrested trying to hack through a secure Alliance server, and Captain Jones agreed to pay his bail. Works closely with Emma to keep the Phoenix running, and gets to “play” with any computer gear they salvage.


Alona Tal – Justine Taylor
A beautiful but somewhat troubled young woman, Justine is only kept around because she’s so damn good at her job. She can use pretty much any weapon out there, and build a bomb out of bathroom supplies. Doesn’t really get the point of most human interaction, and prefers to stay focussed on her work.

Echo Station Staff:

Torri Higginson – Sophie Parker
A highly intelligent and resourceful woman, it is thanks to Sophie that Echo Station has flourished. As the head of the station, she must walk a fine line between the three factions, and isn’t afraid to get her hands dirty if necessary. Setting up and advisory council with representatives of the three factions was originally her idea, one that she sometimes regrets. Her closest friend is John Kane, her Head of Operations, and there have always been rumours about the two of them…. She initially hires the Phoenix for a simple courier run, but after the deal goes bad and the Phoenix is damaged, she asks the crew to find out what happened.


Alexis Denisof – Jonathon Mason
Absolutely loyal to Sophie, Jonathon Mason was originally a policeman on Terra Prime, until the war. He left the planet and moved to the station, working his way up through security until Sophie promoted him to his current position as Head of Operations. He had hoped that the end of the war would make things simpler, but it looks like he isn’t going to get his wish. He doesn't like the Phoenix or her crew, but has no choice but to trust them.


Lennie James – Julian Miles
A relative newcomer to the station, he initially seems to be just a very good barkeep and fence who sells on a lot of what Marcus brings in. However, as the series unfolds it becomes clear that he is actually far more than he seems.



David Nykl – Nikolas Sokol
Constantly harried, he is the engineer responsible for keeping Echo Station alive. Relies on trade from ships like the Phoenix, but hates having to patch components together. Has a growing friendship with Julian, even if he does overcharge. Sophie relies on him, and he’s never let her down.

Recurring Characters:

Mitch Pileggi – Alliance Representative Colonel William Jones
Blunt to the point of rudeness, Colonel Jones served with distinction during the war. Forced to give up active service after he lost a leg, he’s been given the worst job he can imagine; trying to deal with a bunch of criminals and rogues in a shithole in the middle of nowhere. Nonetheless, he’s been given a job, and he’s damn well going to ensure that the Alliance doesn’t lose one inch of ground to the other factions.


Idris Elba – Pegasus Corporation representative Victor Cornell
Smart and pleasant, but also absolutely ruthless, Victor emerged as a shining star in the Pegasus corporation. Sophie suspects that he hopes to gradually increase the corporation’s influence over Echo Station, but only he knows what he’s really up to.


Amy Acker – Free Systems representative Rebecca Adler
It might initially seem that Rebecca is overmatched on the council, but it soon becomes clear that her delicate build hides an iron core. She fiercely believes in the importance of Echo Station, and won’t let the Free Systems be absorbed by the Alliance or Pegasus without a fight.

Well, there you go. It might not work in the long-term, but I reckon there's a pretty good miniseries in there. Also, my apologies to for wandering quite so far away from the prompt (though I managed to get Jake + Heather from "Jericho" in there, so that's something!)

Forgot to post a follow-up to my last - I didn't get the job, or the other one. It sucks, but in the current market just making it to the final round is actually an achievement (albeit a very frustrating one). I actually got told by one of them that I was one of the last ones ruled out, but I didn't convey enough "excitability" - apparently I come across as too analytical (though one person said I had "gravitas" which I find funny as hell!)

At the moment I'm kinda stuck in limbo - some agencies will be launching schemes in the New Year, and I've signed up to a couple of specialist recruitment agencies who seem quite impressed with my CV, but until January nothing's likely to happen. It's frustrating as hell, but it's clear that the entire industry is suffering, and the agencies that are running schemes are massively over subscribed - one place had 2000 applicants for 6 places.

In other news, I'm off to see Avatar with some friends this afternoon. It's in 2D, as I don't want to drive through ice and snow to Milton Keynes to see it in 3D - if I like it, might go back next year and see it in 3D. 

Also, Chuck is airing again in January! For such a great show, there really isn't enough good fanfic, so it'll be nice to get some new episodes.

Merry Christmas/Happy Holidays to all.

Had a final-round job interview last week - the agency said they'd call to let us know today. Am supposed to be preparing for a different interview on Monday, but am actually just staring at my phone willing it to ring.

This is agony!

So.... I liked it

<lj-cut>
It wasn't great- the post sex scene was pretty painful, and I'm annoyed that Chloe + Scott are sleeping together *already*, but Eli's reaction made up for it (I swear, I'm not shipping anyone in this show, but if I was, it would be Eli + Chloe - cliched, but cute).

The effects were brilliant - shots of the sun from the observation deck were stunning.

The plot was incredibly predictable, to the point that my dad guessed how it would go from the end of the previous episode, but it was nicely done, and deliberately paced without being too slow. The ending, with the last minute shuttle catch, was well done too.

I didn't really like the ending with Rush + Young - it didn't make sense that he knew what would happen, as they still sent the shuttle off with all the supplies - it was trying to make him mysterious, and failed.

Still, it's getting better episode to episode - this could turn into a good show

</lj-cut>
Can someone tell me why a show this good wasn't picked up by another network when CBS pulled the plug? It's just too good to end so quickly, damnit.

So, I saw the first two eps. My thoughts, with limited spoilers, under the cut.
<lj-cut>
It's not bad. I wasn't blown away by it, certainly not as much as Atlantis (there wasn't a moment to match the rising of the city), but probably better than SG-1's pilot. The plot worked as a set-up, and some of the characters are quite good - Lt Scott, and Dr Rush in particular. Effects wise, the opening battle was fine, and the ship looks pretty cool. Seeing it in HD helped. Some characters were seriously under-used - you wouldn't know that the IOA lady was a main character.

My big problem is the writing. One scene, between Chloe and Lt Scott, was actually painful to watch. The rest of it seemed to be reaching towards BSG, and not quite getting there. I seem to recall reading that they were bringing in new writers - hopefully this'll result in it improving.

Overall, a decent start to what could (and I'm really, really stressing *could*) be a really good show. As it stands, I'm not convinced.

</lj-cut>

I watched the show with my mum. She watched SG-1, and started to watch Atlantis, but basically stopped post season 3 (wise, wise choice). She asked me how Atlantis ended. I'm amazed by how angry I can still get at that episode!

Huh, forgot to post since I got home. 

My friend and I survived the holiday intact - actually, it was probably the best trip I've done. We did so much out there it's hard to believe that we were only there for two and a half weeks. Might post a couple of pics, if I can figure out how - won't be for a few days as I'm doing a work placement in London at the moment and I'm not really conscious by the time I get home!

In other news, Supernatural season 5 starts airing tomorrow in the US. I'm really ridiculously in love with this show, and thought I'd share a small bit of awesomeness from Jensen Ackles:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HsyMtYoSkC0&feature=related

Awesome. Seriously. Watch this show.

I'm writing this about two hours before I head to the train station to catch a 12 hour overnight train to the Khao sok national park - the brochure described this as fan cooled sleeping berths - our guide Pete (who's a woman) tells us it's going to be 20 bunk beds to a carriage, with a squat toilet and the doors between carriages locked from 10 pm. Thankfully my stomach has been fine so far as otherwise this might go very badly - as it is we're stocked up with crisps, biscuits and bananas, and there's a bar on board so if all else fails we can drink ourselves into oblivion! 

Met the group we'll (I'm here with one of my best friends, Adam) be travelling south with last night - I'm impressed by the Australian couple in their early fifties - pretty adventurous given that this is a very basic holiday. There's also a german couple in their mid twenties - haven't tried speaking to them in German yet. I was surprised, and a bit disappointed, that there aren't more people our age, but we'll deal - probably go off and do our own stuff in the day and meet up in the evening + for transport - they all seem nice, which is the most important thing I guess.

Bangkok is.... somewhat overwhelming, to be honest. It's very hot and humid - about the same as Hong Kong, manically busy, noisy, smelly... you name it. Khao San road is the main tourist street, and it's packed - hate to think what this is like in the high season. We've seen an incredible amount of stuff in just three days - Golden Mount, iron monastery, Wat Pho, the palace, the national museum Jim Thompson's house, the city aquarium, and so on. It was the Queen's birthday on Wednesday night, which was amazing - they sealed off a large chunk of the city to traffic and put up stages with music and dancing, thai boxing (very brutal - makes British boxers look like wimps), snake charming, and hundreds of vendors. It was good to see something real, outside the tourist bubble. That was the only place we really got stared at - most people you meet are friendly (and trying to sell you something). It's been interesting, but I'm glad to be moving on.  

Basically, I'm generally having a great time, with the odd "oh god, what am I doing here" moment. I've no idea what the next two weeks will be like, but will just have to wait and see......

Well, I'm basically packed, and am flying off to Thailand with one of my best mates tomorrow. Land in Bangkok, have two days to wander around, then join a tour heading down the west coast of Thailand, Malaysia, and ending up in Singapore. 

Exciting! And also somewhat scary - I've never done anything like this before, but I'm looking forward to it. Just want to get going now.....

One for the Chuck fans out there:

<lj-embed id="2"/>

Contains no spoilers for anything, but may lead to loud and embarrassing singing - if you're anything like me, anyway!

Man, there's been a lot going on lately. I've graduated, which is a relief as it means I never have to see some people again (though I've made some great friends who I plan to hang on to, there were a few people I ended up ducking around corners every time I saw them, just to avoid awkward conversation). I've got 8 weeks work exp lined up in two blocks of 4 weeks, with a three week gap in which I'm going to Thailand + Malaysia with some friends (so excited!) - assuming I don't get swine flu from riding the tube every day......

It's kind of strange - on the one hand I'm working and commuting every day (which is why I'm so tired), but I'm also living at home - some strange middle ground between uni and the real world. Hopefully one of these will lead into a job that pays enough to move somewhere vaguely close to London.

In other news, does anyone watch True Blood? It premiered in the UK yesterday and I recorded it, but haven't got round to watching it......
Anyone watch Torchwood? Did not expect that ending.....

Well, building my pc took longer than I thought, and the first time I switched it on nothing happened, but it's now working with Windows 7 - can't even express the relief!

To celebrate, I do the dance of joy: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t20KguJbanA

Just ordered the necessary components to build myself a pc. Not really sure why I've chosen to do this, as up until now the most I've done is slot in a new graphics card and some extra RAM, so it's a bit of a step up to building the thing from scratch! Still, found some good online guides, so fingers crossed......

Well, I got a 2:1 degree. Not really a shock as I'd done the maths after getting my final essays back, but it's nice to confirm. I'm now packing up my entire life - not sure I'm going to fit in the car once it's all in.

Got two weeks of work experience lined up, and inquires from two other agencies about it - may not be a job, but it's a start. I think I'm going to be commuting to London a lot in the near future.

Started watching the Sopranos - not in love with it yet, but that's how I felt about The Wire, and now it's my offical Best Show Ever (TM).

Just ordered parts to build my own computer. Got some good deals, now I just have to build the damn thing without breaking anything or electrocuting myself......

And lastly, after marathoning 5 seasons of The West Wing with one of my housemates, it is again confirmed as my official Favourite Show Ever (TM).

Well, it's still coming back, but looks like we'll be waiting a while for it: http://uk.tv.ign.com/articles/983/983822p1.html

10 months! How are we supposed to wait until next March? I have a horrible feeling the ratings are going to be through the floor, and it'll vanish after season 3......

So, I went to see Star Trek a couple of days ago. I liked most of it - the majority of the characters were good, it looked incredible, and it managed to still feel like trek (even though the plot is basically Star Wars in a slightly different universe) However, I do have some problems with it.

<lj-cut> Basically, the more I thought about Nero + his plan, the more it became clear that he and his entire crew had to have been driven insane by all the time travel because how the hell does blowing up a bunch of federation planets save romulus in the future?! Wouldn't it be more sensible to just go and warn the Romulans that there's going to be a supernova near their planet? Not to mention the weirdness of the red matter (that was clearly taken from the set of alias) that can both open up a black hole *and* some kind of space-time rift that ships can safely travel through.

Basically, it DIDN'T MAKE SENSE.

Still liked the film and the setting up of an AU - I just hope the next one is a bit more coherent. </lj-cut>

Chuck has been renewed!! *Does the dance of joy* Only 13 episodes, but this is still great news. People, if you're not watching this show, please start. You can see all of seasons 1+2 online at hulu.com - catch up before the next season starts!

Everyone out there who gets BBC 2, please watch The Wire tonight at 11.20. It's without doubt the finest work of drama ever produced for television, and though it's initially very hard to get into (it took me about 5 episodes to really get hooked) it's undeniably fantastic. I have no idea why the BBC are airing it as they are (the language and content - sex, drugs, violence - might have something to do with the timing), as it's on every night during the week, but just give it a chance. Finding this show was rather like the first time I read a shakespearian play - everything since has been judged against it.
My brain hurts. That is all.

I don't know how many of you watch Supernatural, but damn this new season has been something special. Spoilers up to 410 under the cut.

<lj-cut>
I was so skeptical about the angels idea, but it's really paid off - it's not the same show it was back in the early seasons, but I think it's gotten better. The one-offs are as good as they ever were (a depressed, suicidal teddy bear, anyone?), but the overarching plot is much more gripping than last season's. 

The latest two-parter is an example of how good the show can get. The final scene, where Dean tells Sam what happened to him in Hell - that's probably the most powerful scene in the series so far. Makes me wonder if that was what happened to John Winchester, and how long he lasted. I hope that Anna comes back later on, as she was a great character - I kinda liked the idea of Sam, Dean, a demon and an angel!

Lastly, Alistair must die. I hate that guy a hell of a lot more than Lillith, and about the same as I hated old yellow-eyes.
</lj-cut>

The ratings for this season have been good, so hopefully it'll be renewed - it would be a shame to cut this storyline short. Can't wait to see where it goes from here.

Man, I really do suck at updating this thing. For those of you who were worried (you were worried, right?), I'm still alive, and still at Bristol. University's going fairly well, although it's kinda scary that I have 6 essays to go and then I'm going to graduate. That said, I haven't exactly had the best university career, and I do know what I want to do after I graduate - I may be the only person in my year who's actually looking forward to leaving university! I'm filling out applications for grad schemes at the moment, and it's hard - I've already had two rejections, but all you can do is just keep trying and hoping.

And now, a brief summary of what I'm watching and my thoughts:
Atlantis - We've had some good episodes this season, but it's never going to be what it could have been. Hopefully the writers will learn some lessons from it and apply them to Universe - even though I am still very dubious about that one. I read somewhere that Kavan Smith was hoping to jump ship to Universe, to which I can only say "Hell yes". If he could take David Nikyl as well that would be great.

Burn Notice - Does anyone else watch this? It's a great show, which suffers a bit with a 'problem of the week' approach, but the actors make it work. Also has some great guest stars - Richard Schiff, Tricia Helfer, and Michael Shanks (not all in the same episode, sadly).

Supernatural - I was skeptical about the whole "angels" plotline, but it's actually worked really well. The overarching storyline is far more interesting this season than the whole "Dean's going to hell", and some of the one-off episodes have been wonderful. Everyone should watch Wishful Thinking, for the best supernatural manifestation ever.

House - love this. Only on season 3, and I'm confused by all the House/Cuddy stuff that's starting to come in (and apparently gets more prominent in later seasons), but it's still great. 

Heroes - *sigh*. This was such a good show in the first season, but now it's starting to annoy me. They constantly contradict what happened in earlier seasons, which for a guy like me (who remembers every little detail of television shows) is just plain aggravating. Still entertaining, but I don't care about this anymore.

The Wire - Watch this show. Seriously, everyone go and watch this show right now. This isn't television, it's art. Buy it, watch it, and start talking about it. It's initially hard to watch, but once you get into it, it's incredible.

I'm writing this in a cyber cafe and my money is about to run out so I'm making this quick. The job's been fantastic, I've got two weeks left, and it's gone by fast. I don't have the net at home yet (BT is officially this universe's incarnation of Wolfram & Hart), hence the cyber cafe.

My thoughts on stargate universe were optimistic, till I read this:
http://www.gateworld.net/news/2008/08/sci_fi_explains_hopes_for_istarg.shtml

"skew it younger?" - is anyone else having visions of SG-1's 200th ep clip?

It's been four weeks since I started work - I've got four more weeks to go. Can't believe I'm half way through - it's gone by so fast! Between evening sessions in London with the other people on the course + traveling home / to see friends at the weekends I'm averaging two full evenings in Bristol a week - it's crazy, I'm exhausted, and I'm having a fantastic time! The downside is that I still don't have the net in my house, and though they're pretty relaxed about surfing at work I'm not all that keen to explain the whole fandom thing so I've basically been out of touch with everything for the last few weeks. Having seen the stuff about the next ep of Atlantis that may not be such a bad thing.

Also - Dark Knight was awesome, but personally I'd rate Gary Oldman, Aaron Eckhart + Christian Bale as being as good as Ledger.

Saw Die Hard 4 - nothing like the originals but still damn entertaining (perhaps Lucas + Spielberg should have watched it before embarking on the travesty that was Kingdom of the Cristal Skull!)

Lastly, everyone go buy The Wire. Right now. Seriously, it's probably the second best show I've ever seen (after West Wing), and I say that having only seen the first season.

Man, I suck at updating this thing. I'm not dead, far from it in fact. I start work tomorrow at a small digital marketing agency (no, I've no idea what it means either!) in Bristol for two months. I'm both excited and nervous - excited because this could be a huge step towards a career after graduating, nervous because I've no idea what it'll be like. Also I'm not that keen on going back to Bristol - I love the city but my university experience has just plain sucked. The few friends I have down there are of course off on holiday, so my evenings may be fairly dull/lonely. That said, I'm going to be working 8.30-5.30 + going to London at least one night a week, as well as coming home, visiting friends or having friends down most weekends. I suspect these 8 weeks are going to fly by. Just have to get down there and get into it.


Best thing is I even get paid!

Anyone else watch "Chuck"? I saw the first episode a while back and wasn't all that impressed, but over the last 3 days I've watched the whole first season. I love it - the perfect balance of action + comedy, and Chuck/Sarah is my new OTP (which may be a first - a pairing with an actual chance of happening someday!)

Good God, it's been nearly two months since I've posted anything! I am still alive, still at uni, and still without housing for next year *sigh*

In more important news, Martin Sheen (of West Wing fame) and Ed Byrne (who's just a really funny guy) were the guests on the Graham Norton show. Watch it here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/page/item/b00b2d2w.shtml

You have to love the BBC iplayer (even if the name is a tad unoriginal!)
Supernatural has got another season! This is good news, just have to keep my fingers crossed for Jericho now.....

It suddenly occurred to me that I hadn't wished anyone Happy New Year. So, yeah, Happy New Year. Haven't got anything else to say, but I'm bored writing an essay and I thought what the hell. As for how I am - my icon says it all. Let's just hope 2008's an improvement.
Well, everyone else is doing it - if anyone has any questions about me, my views on any subject, anything really - then feel free to ask, but I won't be insulted if no one does!

I just spent the last two days reading an epic Harry Potter fanfic. Harry Potter fanfic. I have never even gone near the fandom, and suddenly I'm reading something that's as long as the bloody books!

It's official - my journey to the dark side has begun. Shoot me now.

(By the way, the story was "After the End", containing both Hermione/Ron and Harry/Ginny, with spoilers only up to the end of the fourth book yet set in an AU after the defeat of Voldemort. It can be found here: http://www.sugarquill.net/read.php?storyid=619&chapno=1)

In other fandom news, I've discovered that gen Atlantis fic can actually be good, as demonstrated by "The Therapeutic Properties of Coffee" http://liketheriverrun.livejournal.com/11390.html . There is Katy/Rodney ship, but it's a background to the friendship between John + Rodney.

The best story I've read in ages can be found here: http://www.kekkai.org/synecdochic/sga/freedoms_just_another_word.html

It's set after the expedition has returned to Earth, and looks at Rodney settling into life on Earth. There is some slash, but it's never described in any detail whatsoever apart from that a relationship existed and the relationship has ended by the time of the story. I never go near slash but the writing on this one is too good to pass up.

Enjoy, hopefully. Don't blame me if you end up wasting a lot of time in the near future.

So, when you have a conversation with a girl (who you've been crazy about for two years) in which she admits she has feelings for you, but isn't ready for a relationship, and actually uses the words "talk to me again in a few months"..... and then six weeks later you see on facebook she's started dating someone else....... probably doesn't bode well, right?

*reaches for the whiskey*

As the subject line suggests, I'm feeling a bit crap. More details under the cut.
<lj-cut>
I've been back in Bristol for a week now and if things don't get better in the next few weeks I honestly don't think I'm going to last until Christmas, let alone until the end of the year. Firstly, second-year life is *hard* - cooking, cleaning, dealing with stupid stuff like the trash collection and sorting out the internet in the flat. On top of that, I'm living with two guys who are nice but I have nothing in common with, and I'm spending a good 70% of my time on my own. I've completely lost my appetite to the point where I actively feel nauseous when I eat my breakfast, and I've been ringing home about every other day. Several of these conversations have ended with me in tears (and I never cry - not even at funerals). I'm trying to make an effort and visit friends + join societies, but it's been fresher's week so I haven't had much work + no societies have been running. Most of my friends are in two big houses, and I just don't feel that I can pop round whenever I feel like it, even though they are being very welcoming. Going out with them is fun, but the moment always comes when I have to go back to the flat alone. Every morning I'm waking up very early and all I want is to jump on a train and go home.

My parents have said that I can come home next weekend, but I just don't think that that will help - I just have to gut it out. That said, if things haven't improved in three weeks then I'm definately going to go home for the weekend..

</lj-cut>

Haven't posted for a while, so here's what I've been up to. <lj-cut>

Well, I spent most of the last 8 weeks working for a salvage company, arranging to collect vehicles that have been damaged too badly to repair. This has taught me that all cheap insurance companies are evil, and should be avoided like the plague - the number of times I spoke to someone who couldn't understand why we'd been instructed to collect the vehicle.... well, it was eye-opening, to say the least. Still, it was easy enough work + the pay was good (for a student). I might go back there next year, if I have nothing better to do / need the money again.

In two weeks I head back to Bristol - I have mixed feelings over that one - I'm not living with my friends, but rather with two guys who I get on fine with but am not that close with - the whole saga of accomodation occupied most of the Easter term last year, and means that I'm honestly not sure I'm going to see the people who were my good friends. After spending time with my school friends it's kinda scary to think of going back there and potentially starting all over again. Even worse, my essays + exams actually matter this year! On the other hand, I think I will probably still see my friends from the hall, albeit not as much as I would like, and I'm looking foward to seeing my other friends, the ones who weren't involved in the whole housing debacle. Even better, one of my best friends from home is starting at Bristol this year, and having her around is enough to make up for all the other issues.

So that's that - it was a quiet but enjoyable summer, with some brilliant moments (Reading Festival was a highlight - to see one of the best bits from that look at this: <lj-embed id="1" /> 

Standing there watching that with my friends was just incredible.

p.s. Anyone who is even remotely interested in gaming has got to buy Bioshock - it's more mature, intelligent and thought-provoking than the average show or movie, and has one of the greatest twists EVER. Also, the voice acting makes most tv shows pale in comparison. And The West Wing is still amazing, as is Dexter - an unusual show well worth checking out, and not just because the lead actor has the same name as me (seriously, he even has the same middle initial!)
</lj-cut>

Found this on a site - the questions are kinda obvious but I was as honest as possible - I'm not surprised at the outcome!


Ahh, the ever-cynical and sarcastic speechwriter. Gutsy and not afraid to speak up or clash with authority, his dry wit is amusing. But under it all he's just a big teddy bear... and the world's biggest Yankees fan.

:: Which West Wing character are you? ::

Just saw it with a friend, and I liked it. Graphically, it's the most perfect film I've ever seen - there's not a moment when you can tell the difference between CGI and giant models. On top of that, it's actually funny, for the most part (there's one bit with a government agency man that's misjudged). There's a lot of cheesy bits, but if you're looking for a mindless, entertaining summer blockbuster, look no further.
Can anyone point me in the direction of some good Supernatural gen or het fic? I'd go looking myself, but that fandom scares the hell out of me. Any Jo/Dean in particular would be great.

Jericho's been renewed for a midseason pickup! Only 8 eps but it's a start.

Also, went to see 28 weeks later last night. I really liked it - the plot made very little sense but there are some superb scenes, and Robert Carlyle is particularly good. It only lost it in one scene with a helicopter which turned into a horror-comedy moment, but other than that it held together really well. Whoever did the special effects deserves an award. I should warn you, a couple of my friends came out pretty traumatised. I didn't think it was that bad (it's certainly not a horror porn film like Saw or Hostel, thank god), but if you don't like gory films then I wouldn't see it. Otherwise, go and enjoy!

Man that's annoying - the show had 8 million viewers but apparently that wasn't enough - hopefully some other network will see the show's potential and pick it up.


In other news, I have 7,000 words due in tomorrow. God I can't wait to go to the pub afterwards!

That pretty much sums up how I feel right now. I started drinking yesterday at 2p.m., went on a very long bar crawl, then went out to a club. I stopped drinking at 2a.m. On the plus side I took my new camera out and didn't lose it. Even better, there are no shots of me on the album! Still, no alcohol for a few days, I think.

Man I'm having a lazy day. My seminar got moved to 4 p.m instead of 11 a.m, so I've basically spent the day watching tv. Saw the newest heroes (good, but with a few twists I'm not happy with), and a really cool Russion film, Night Watch. It's interesting, kinda like Buffy meets the cold war by way of the X-Files - hard to describe, but well worth watching (apparently it and its sequel have grossed more in Russia than the entire Lord of the Rings trilogy!) Also watched The Blair Witch Project with some friends last night. It's amazing what they did with little more than a few piles of rocks and some interestingly arranged twigs!

Ah well, better go finish reading the book for my Seminar - "How Late it was, How Late" by James Kelman.

I just finished watching one of the most worrying programmes I've ever seen. It's called "The Most Hated Family in America" and was about a Christian Church / family who picket military funerals in the US. They believe that the soldiers are dying as a punishment from God for America tolerating gay people. That such a level of ignorance and intolerance can still exist is quite frankly terrifying. The worst thing was watching a nine year old boy holding a sign with the words "Fag Soldiers" on it. He clearly had no real understanding of why they were there or what it all meant. To see something like that truly challenges my belief in free speech. These people are free to believe what they want, and to tell people their beliefs, but picketing a dead soldier's funeral.... that's a terrible and difficult thing to allow. I strongly urge anyone and everyone to watch this show if they get the chance.

To see clips from the show, go here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbctwo/noise/?id=louis_theroux

To see what I would say to these people, go here: http://youtube.com/watch?v=rWuXpfXSl5Y&mode=related&search=
As usual, I can't hope to match the brilliant writing of Mister Aaron Sorkin.

Well, I just watched it - my thoughts, with spoilers, under the cut
<lj-cut>
It seems like this is another marmite ep - and I loved it. Dominion gave us the lead into the films, this served more as a tribute to the show and to the fans. I liked but wasn't surprised by the Daniel/Vala stuff - that was clearly the way the show's been going (although I really liked the bit where Daniel just snapped and started to vent - it's good to show that side of him. I did think that having Landry there was a bit strange, but it worked okay. A lot of people seem to be raging against the death of the Asgard, but we've known that their race was dying for about 5 series now, so it didn't bother me, and I liked their sacrificing themselves for their friends. I'm a little surprised by the way that Asgard tech now seems superior to Ori tech (contrast that with their performance in Camelot), but I'll overlook it. Not having Jack there was.... difficult. I would have loved to finally see a proper relationship between Jack and Sam, but ultimately I think that Richard Dean Anderson left the show after the eighth season, so it arguably wouldn't have been fair to have him waltzing back in when the show wants us to say goodbye to the current cast members.

 The most moving parts for me were the moment when Thor tells them that they are "The Fifth Race", concluding a process that began all the way back in season 2, as well the series of shots interwoven with the cello. The final scene itself was a celebration of the essence of the show - the group "indeed" and Landry's "Godspeed" had me bouncing in my seat (yes, seriously, I bounced), and the final shot..... well, it couldn't have been better.

Although I'm still frustrated by the forced curtailment of the Ori storyline (I'm still not convinced by the idea of TV films), this was undeniably a fitting end to the show, if not the story. More than that, it summed up why stargate has lasted ten years. Many, including myself, think that Galactica is a superior show. It has tenser storylines, more flawed characters, and less of a reliance on deus ex endings. But if you gave me a choice between the two shows, I'd still choose Stargate. It offers a world of wisecracking heroes and malevolent villains, where you can always believe that good will triumph over evil. It may not be as "realistic" as Galactica, but it's a world that I would like to be a part of - and isn't that the whole point?

Bring on the new spin-off, and good luck to all the cast and crew. It's been one hell of a ride.
</lj-cut>

My magical alterations to tv can be found under the cut.....
<lj-cut>


You can go back in time and erase from the fabric of TV history THREE individual episodes of any TV show you want! The rest of the series(es) will not be altered. What do you choose?

1. It would be Irresistable, but Lucius would survive in Irresponsible, so I'm going to have to go with The Tower *shudder*

2. A third series ep of Buffy called "Amends"

3. The O.C. third season finale "The Graduates". It would almost have been a good way to finish the show, until the last 2 minutes which were just stupid. I get why they did it, but I just couldn't be bothered to watch the fourth season after that.

You can go back in time and revive ONE unfairly cancelled television show and return it to the annals of TV history!* *CHOOSE WISELY, because if you attempt to revive more than one show, the wish will backfire and you'll instead be treated to a whole bunch of crappy made-for-TV "reunion" movies full of replacement actors.

I would say The West Wing, but it ended at a logical point so instead I'm saying Angel - it just got better and better towards the end. Joss Whedon did his best to tie everything up, but you could see that the plotlines could have easily gone for another year. That said, the finale was genius

To balance out the historical TV viewing schedule, you now have the power to retroactively CANCEL, at any point during the series, any one show! Alternately, you can wield your destructive might and DELETE one whole entire series from ever having been made. 

Big Brother. Enough said.

LIFE AND DEATH! You can now bring ONE character back from the dead... and, to restore the balance, you must also kill off a character! They don't have to be from the same fandom. 

Fred. If you know who that is, you know why.

Kill someone off? Claire from Lost. In the first series I hated her, Boone and Shannon. 

Bonus tradeoff: you can delete a single scene, relationship pairing or plot arc from any series that gave you hives... AND you can plug in any one [scene, pairing, plot arc] that you never got to see!

Sheyla.

Fred/Wesley. Two series of hoping, and then to have that happen?!?!?!?!?
</lj-cut>

It's snowing right outside my window!!!!!!!

That is all.
